docs.snippet: Peru advanced to the Copa América quarterfinals by coming from behind twice — the second time playing a man short — to tie Bolivia, 2-2, last night in Mérida, Venezuela. Venezuela and Uruguay tied, 0-0, in a later match. Each will...
docs.lead_paragraph: Peru advanced to the Copa América quarterfinals by coming from behind twice — the second time playing a man short — to tie Bolivia, 2-2, last night in Mérida, Venezuela. Venezuela and Uruguay tied, 0-0, in a later match. Each will advance to the knockout round.

docs.snippet: Conmebol, the South American soccer confederation, is seriously miffed at the United States for sending a team with little international experience to the Copa.
docs.lead_paragraph: Join us here at 6:30 Eastern time today for the US-Colombia match, the finale for both teams at the Copa América and one that will have absolutely no bearing on the tournament, since both have been mathematically eliminated. Duncan Irving will have what might well be the unpleasant task of bringing you the live description of that game.
docs.abstract: Conmebol, the South American soccer confederation, is seriously miffed at the United States for sending a team with little international experience to the Copa.

headline.main: Live Today: USA-Colombia ... if Conmebol Doesn't Kick Them Out First

docs.snippet: Note how well certain invited teams have done: Mexico, certainly, and one-time guest Honduras -- and how poorly other guests have done; namely, the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: With group play completed and the knockout round about to begin, here is a look at how nations have done in the 41 previous editions of the Copa América. Note how the South American big three --Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil -- dominate the tournament, having won 35 Copas among them. Those three countries, plus Chile, made up the entire field in the inaugural 1916 tournament.
docs.abstract: Note how well certain invited teams have done: Mexico, certainly, and one-time guest Honduras -- and how poorly other guests have done; namely, the United States.

docs.snippet: The dead-rubber games and dead wood have all gone away. Now, the Copa America gets down to business with a pair of doubleheader quarterfinals today and tomorrow.
docs.lead_paragraph: The dead-rubber games and dead wood have all gone away. Now, the Copa America gets down to business with a pair of doubleheader quarterfinals today and tomorrow.Sensing that the world hasn't seen enough of matches involving Venezuela and Uruguay, the organizers have pitted them against each other again in the opening quarterfinal. No doubt this is to keep the local hopes alive, as Uruguay has shown little in its opening three games.The Copa bloggers are giving this one a pass, but join Duncan Irving for live updates of the nightcap and banner matchup between Brazil and Chile. Coverage starts a 8:45 p.m. eastern.
docs.abstract: The dead-rubber games and dead wood have all gone away. Now, the Copa America gets down to business with a pair of doubleheader quarterfinals today and tomorrow.

headline.main: Live Tonight from the Copa America: Chile-Brazil

docs.snippet: Hello everyone and welcome to our continuing coverage of the Copa America.
docs.lead_paragraph: For live updates of tonight's Brazil-Chile game by Duncan Irving, click "read more" then bash your F5 or "refresh" key to keep current.
docs.abstract: Hello everyone and welcome to our continuing coverage of the Copa America.

docs.snippet: Maracanã stadium, the shrine of Brazilian soccer in Rio de Janeiro, is closed. The national sport is on hold, awaiting the start of the Pan American Games on Friday and the promise of future glory that a successful sports showcase could bring.
docs.lead_paragraph: Maracanã stadium, the shrine of Brazilian soccer in Rio de Janeiro, is closed. The national sport is on hold, awaiting the start of the Pan American Games on Friday and the promise of future glory that a successful sports showcase could bring.

docs.snippet: Striker Diego Forlán scored twice as Uruguay knocked host Venezuela out of the Copa América with a 4-1 victory in a quarterfinal in San Cristobal. Uruguay advanced to a semifinal game against Brazil, which routed Chile, 6-1, in Puerto La...
docs.lead_paragraph: Striker Diego Forlán scored twice as Uruguay knocked host Venezuela out of the Copa América with a 4-1 victory in a quarterfinal in San Cristobal. Uruguay advanced to a semifinal game against Brazil, which routed Chile, 6-1, in Puerto La Cruz.
